thread.title: Star power: 4 Dallas restaurants that want to dazzle you this spring
thread.title_full: Star power: 4 Dallas restaurants that want to dazzle you this spring

author: Leslie Brenner
title: Star power: 4 Dallas restaurants that want to dazzle you this spring
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
After what feels like a six-month hibernation, Dallas' chef-driven dining scene is finally starting to wake up -- not quietly, but with a roar! 
A couple of places have already opened, with two more high-profile debuts planned between now and midsummer. All are super splashy, featuring chefs with impressive star power (two involve chefs who have earned five-star reviews). All are downtown or downtownish. If these dining rooms even begin to fulfill their potential, they could turn our city center into a glamorous gastronomic power zone. Mirador, the penthouse restaurant atop Forty Five Ten, features the cooking of executive chefs Josh Sutcliff (left) and Junior Borges. Rose Baca/Staff Photographer Mirador 
With a wraparound terrace that overlooks the giant eyeball, the penthouse restaurant atop Forty Five Ten on Main features the ambitious, gorgeously presented modern American cooking of executive chef Josh Sutcliff in collaboration with Junior Borges, executive chef of the Joule Hotel. (Forty Five Ten and the Joule are both owned by Headington Companies). 
Mirador , Forty Five Ten on Main, penthouse level, 1608 Elm St., Dallas; 214-945-8200. Lunch Monday-Saturday; dinner Thursday-Saturday. Town Hearth A 1961 MG showpiece on display between Town Hearth's open kitchen and its dining room Tom Fox/Staff Photographer 
Massive, fabulous wood-grilled steaks, lobsters roasted in butter and other over-the-top indulgences are the order of the day at Town Hearth , Nick Badovinus' glammy new Design District restaurant. 
Town Hearth, 1617 Market Center Blvd., Dallas. 214-761-1617. Dinner Monday-Saturday. The French Room 
Executive chef Michael Ehlert plans a modern take on French classics when the Adolphus Hotel's historic dining room, closed for a remake since last summer, reopens in late May or perhaps June. Until then, we'll be hungrily anticipating its return. 
Adolphus Hotel , 1321 Commerce St., Dallas; 214-742-8200. Bullion 
Longtime Mansion chef Bruno Davaillon is one of the city's most inspired, so his extended absence from an anemic scene (he left the Mansion in 2015) has been keenly felt. A year and a half in the making, the modern French brasserie he plans to open in early June promises to feature whole roasted birds, escargot beignets, braised rabbit torte, a gold leitmotif, a dramatic staircase. Glorious-sounding indeed. 
400 S. Record St., Dallas. View Comments
